p: Seasonal influenza—a respiratory infectious disease with a high transmissibility rate and worldwide distribution—is caused by influenza A and B viruses [ 1]. Influenza A viruses have been extensively studied due to their association with high genetic variability and severe pandemics [ 2]. On the other hand, influenza B viruses were divided into two genetically and antigenically distinct strains, namely Victoria and Yamagata, in the 1980s [ 3]. However, molecular characterization of influenza B viruses has been little documented because a smaller impact of influenza B virus infection on public health was believed in the past [ 4]. Recently, epidemiological investigations have revealed a massive effect of influenza B on the mortality rate and the severity [ 5, 6]. This evidence has highlighted the need to study the influenza B infections in order to understand the pathogenesis.
